What the Euroepans have done together in the last five years exceeds vastly the fears and expectations people had about Europe. She cites the ESM, the agreement to reduce Greece's massive debt burden, improvement to financial regulations. Lagarde says: Ireland should strive to provide high quality public services. That is much easier said than done when you look at budgetary constraints. She says Ireland must concentrate on health and education. On unemployment, she expresses concern about long-term unemployment. People need to be helped to find jobs. Higher growth typically brings higher unemployment. Employment services need to be revitalised. Lagarde says the efforts are paying off. To look at euro area members there are not many that deliver positive growth. The IMF expects Ireland to grow by 1% this year and 2% next. While Ireland is beginning to see the fruits of success, the harvest is yet to come. She does note unemployment, which she says is still cripplingly high at 14.5% and double that for young people. But says it is coming down for the first time in years. Lagarde notes that Ireland has not had the kind of backlash to austerity that other bailed-out countries have suffered. The government took those decisions while retaining social cohesion. Because of this Ireland was able to resist a large increase in poverty. Lagarde says the Irish government never wavered in its commitment to get beyond the crisis. They pulled together in the national interest and made the hard choices. At the root of the problem, she says was a financial crisis made worse by a real estate crisis. I have to point out one thing. The rigour and the vigour with which that was tackled was exemplary. And the stress test has served as a model in other countries. The government also made huge strides on the budget. During the most difficult of times it introduced deficit reducing measures. This is quite a spectacular love-in so far. Presumably she will recognise that the country still has staggeringly high unemployment. IMF chief Lagarde is full of praise for her hosts. Ireland has always exceeded expectations. Time and time again it has bounced back stronger and more confident than before. This time is no different, she says. Irish finance minister Michael Noonan is introducing "Christine", as he calls her (repeatedly). Christine Lagarde is about to speak in Dublin Castle on "Ireland and the European Union—Shared Determination, Shared Destiny". The rather beautiful hall is packed, and it looks like she is filing in now. These are shocking figures, which expose how out of touch David Cameron was yesterday to claim his economic plan isn’t failing. We need to kick-start our flatlining economy by investing in infrastructure projects and building thousands more affordable homes. And to get small projects moving too VAT on home repairs, maintenance and improvements should be cut to 5 per cent. Labour, business groups, the IMF and now even Vince Cable are calling for action to build our way to a strong and sustained recovery. It’s time the Prime Minister and his downgraded Chancellor realised their plan isn’t working and acted before any more long-term damage is done. Italy may decide to exit the euro or take other drastic action, a German politician and Merkel ally has said, according to Reuters. If Italy does not want to do that, they have to take the consequences. That could mean that they exit (the euro) or that they take drastic measures. But it's down to Italy to decide that. The FDP is one of chancellor Angela Merkel's junior coalition parties. January’s stagnation in German industrial production is a blow to hopes that the economy could recover strongly at the start of this year. But while this suggests that Q4’s 0.6% fall in GDP will not be repeated, it is not consistent with a strong recovery either. This is in line with the message from the composite PMI, which points to modest quarterly gains in GDP of about 0.2%. Further ahead, a further fall in the euro and modest improvement in global demand might mean that the gradual industrial recovery continues. And January’s 1.6% rise in production of consumer goods might suggest that household demand is starting to recover. But with German unemployment now rising and the euro at a high level, we still doubt that the recovery will be as strong as most forecasters expect. Some reaction on Twitter to those grim UK construction figures (see 10.32am)... German industrial output was unchanged in January (compared with the previous month), missing forecasts for a 0.5% increase. That follows disappointing factory orders out yesterday, which dropped by 1.9%, compared with hopes of a 0.6% increase. With the eurozone increasingly relying on Germany for growth, this makes uncomfortable reading. We'll have analyst reaction on that as it comes in. It seems IMF chief Christine Lagarde will be speaking again at 11.30. We'll be covering that or you can watch it live. Sticking with the UK, there are some grim figures out about UK construction. The survey also tries to measure the level of satisfaction (or otherwise) with the way the Bank of England is ‘doing its job’. In addition to these, in February every year the pollsters ask five questions to gauge the perceptions of the relationship between interest rates and inflation and knowledge of who sets rates. Sometimes there is a worry about what is at the end of the road. There is clearly hope at the end of this road. (I've called GfK to find out who these people were and what exactly they were asked. My guess is that the average man on the street does not have a particularly strong opinion on where inflation is headed but I may be wrong. Will update when I hear from them.) That is largely down to a lack of demand, as the eurozone's third-largest economy stays mired in recession. Interest rates on loans in January were below their 2012 average even though volumes declined. Perhaps more importantly bank lending continues to grow slowly, which means there is a chance monetary policy might work. UK FTSE 100: up 0.6%, or 37 points, at 6476 France CAC 40: up 0.8% Germany DAX: up 0.7% Spain IBEX: up 0.9% Italy FTSE MIB: up 0.7% And there was better news out of Japan (which was relegated to being the third-largest economy in the world by China's rapid growth back in 2011). Its government has revised official GDP figures, which now suggest the economy stabilised in the fourth quarter after a brief recession. Initial estimates pointed to a 0.1% contraction, but that has been revised to no change. The Bank of Japan joined the ECB and the Bank of England yesterday in sitting on its hands. But markets expect it to be more aggressive from next month, after new governor Haruhiko Kuroda comes in. There was some upbeat data out of China overnight, with export numbers soaring past forecasts to jump by 22% in February. That suggests global demand is on the mend. But import figures were surprisingly weak, dropping 15.2% from a year earlier, which suggest demand at home could still be a problem. Economists said on balance the data was good news. The world's second largest economy grew by 7.9% in the last quarter of 2012 (from a year earlier), up from 7.4% the previous quarter. Analysts say this data suggests that improvement could continue into the first quarter of this year. Aside from Lagarde's visit to Dublin, there's some economic data to digest today, including the key US jobs report for February. IMF chief Christine Lagarde today touches down in Dublin for an official visit to the bailed-out eurozone state. She sounded an upbeat note ahead of the visit, telling the Irish Times that Europe should do all it can to assist Ireland's return to the financial markets, above and beyond simply stretching out the time it has to pay back the €30bn it owes the European bail-out funds. She said: I would be cautious not to limit it to an extension. I think it has really been refined yesterday during the discussions as an adjustment that might include very much an extension of the maturities but is not limited only to the extension of maturities. She agrees that pushing out the repayments to the end of the term – a so-called bullet payment – is an option, but says there are many others. To the extent that it [a measure] is supportive of Ireland and that it will help smooth the transition into growth and Ireland standing on its own two feet, I think we should explore any avenue. Lagarde will today meet officials from the Irish government, which is hoping to exit its bail-out programme by the end of this year.

webTitle: FTSE 100 pushes to new highs ahead of US employment numbers

fields.standfirst: Banks help market advance once more, with HSBC recovering after Monday's disappointing results
fields.body:
Banks are helping to push leading shares to fresh five year highs, ahead of the US employment data due later.

The FTSE 100 has jumped 20.70 points to 6459.86, hovering around its best levels since the end of 2007. After disappointing results on Monday, HSBC is 16.4p higher at 734.6p as investors buy back into the sector. Lloyds Banking Group has been lifted 0.88p to 50.74p while Barclays is 3p better at 312.5p.

Aviva has added 4p to 318.8p, recovering after Thursday's news of a hefty cut in its dividend, while Schroders continued to benefit from better than expected figures, up 32p to £21.18.

Vodafone has added 2.15p to 180.75p, with shareholders hoping for corporate action revolving around its 45% stake in US group Verizon Wireless. A sale of the stake or a purchase of the whole of Vodafone by its partner Verizon were reportedly discussed at the end of last year, and analysts believe some form of restructuring is inevitable.

But water companies have edged lower on dividend concerns, with United Utilities down 12.5p at 713.5p. Mining groups have fallen back after China reported a 15% fall in imports in February, with Rio Tinto down 52p at £33.98.

Credit Suisse has downgraded the whole sector from neutral to underweight, based on caution about Chinese growth, oversupply and underperformance compared to metal prices.

Traders will be watching the US jobs numbers carefully. Expectations are for a rise of 160,000 in February, up from 157,000 in the previous months. The outcome could prove volatile. If the figure is weaker than expected, that will raise new concerns about the state of the world's biggest economy. If it is stronger, investors could see that as a sign the Federal Reserve may move away from further quantitative easing.
